children.value: This tutorial will help you learn the basic structure of a strategy for Hummingbot. It will guide you through the scope of creating a simple strategy that only fetches market status to building a more complex strategy that can perform trades.
By the end of this tutorial, you should:
Have a general understanding of the base classes that serve as building blocks of the strategies
Be able to build new custom strategies from scratch
We will start with a simple strategy that can perform

command and displays the user's token balance in a given market. This part should expose you to different parts of the Hummingbot codebase, help you understand some core classes frequently referred to when building strategies, and provide a starting point for developing custom strategies.
Take a look at the directory for hello world strategy:
This file allows one to expose certain variables to all modules inside the package by placing the strategy object under
This file contains a type declaration about some variables that are specified in the
This file contains a bulk of functions that define the behavior of strategy. For example, the
function defines the variables that were declared in the
file and initializes fields inherited from
class. All other functions can be customized depending on the behavior that the developer wants to create. For example, an essential function is
because this function chooses which data to render when
This file handles prompting the user for config values when the strategy is called. Each key value of the
assigned where a developer can specify the prompt and assign validators to check for accepted values.
function gets called when the user calls the strategy on the client-side. This function should handle the initialization of configs by calling
, set market names and wallets, and eventually execute the strategy.
: Renders information about the current strategy and markets. The information that you want to be displayed can be customized with
: Prompts users asking for details about strategy set up (e.g. token, market name, etc). Prompts can be modified in
class. This class allows extraction of logic that would be repetitively written in all strategies otherwise.

: The client's prompt eventually leads to changes on a server with the help of event listeners. Depending on the action taken by the client, corresponding event listeners are called to execute the right job.
: The base class handles the creation of data frames for market status,
, so it is easy for developers to create and access about particular markets.
The base class also contains methods that are meant to be freshly implemented when new strategies are created.
: set up logger for strategy session
: define format of status that will be rendered on Hummingbot client
To help you develop custom strategies, overridable functions that respond to various events is detected by EventListeners.

class contains overridable functions that can help get basic information about an exchange that a strategy is operating on, including the balance, prices, and order books for any particular asset traded on the exchange.
: called when the user wants to place a buy order
: called when the user wants to place a sell order
: called when the user wants to place an order cancellation
: called to get the user’s balance of assets
: called to get the user’s available balance of assets
: called when the user wants to withdraw assets
: called to get the order book for any particular asset
: called to get the price for any particular asset
: called to get the quantum price of an order
: called to get the quantum size of an order
: called to quantize the price of an order
: called to quantize the amount of an order
: called to get the fee for exchange use
listener object to check if buy/sell orders have been filled or completed. It also reports if the user has enough balance between placing specific orders and any order cancellations. The
object is used for logging the specific events when they occur.
Exposing new strategy to Hummingbot client
Make strategy name known to the client by adding a name to
variable. There should also be a template file that contains config variables and its documentation in the
directory. The naming convention for this yml file is
Setting question prompts for strategy parameters
Strategy parameters can be set in the
file. Each parameter (represented as dictionary key) is mapped to a
type where a developer can specify the parameter's name, prompts that will be provided to the user, and a validator that will check the values entered.
We will extend what we built on step 1 and add a feature that will load the order book for a market. This part will help developers understand how to read data from different data frames.
This strategy extends the Hello World Strategy by loading an order book in a given market. When the command
is executed, the strategy fetches and enumerates the order book data (maker orders) by retrieving the
data frame for the market that the strategy is operating on. If there are no active orders, "No active maker orders." is printed.

In the Perform Trade strategy, Hummingbot places a single order that the user specifies. Unlike Simple Trade, orders will not be canceled after a certain amount of time and are only set once at the start of the strategy.
Here's a high-level view of the logic flow inside the built-in perform trade strategy.

children.alt: Figure 1: Perform trade strategy flow chart

children.value: The flow of the strategy is as follows.
Before the strategy attempts to perform any trades, it checks the following to ensure it is safe to complete the trade:
Are both markets ready and connected?
Does the user have enough balance?
Additionally, this check triggers a warning and logs the warning. If the user does not have the requisite balance to perform the trade, the interface will display the warning.
To achieve this check, the Perform Trade strategy gets the user's available balance by using the

Order state is tracked using the quantity, price, type, id, and other attributes.
The OrderTracker class includes functions monitoring when order tracking begins, noticing and tracking cancels, and tracking ends. When an order is completed, an order id is returned, and the specifics concerning the order can be determined by using the OrderTracker class.

The order state, specifically, whether the order is partially or completely filled is managed by events in the MarketBase class. Specifically, the logic regarding order creation, cancelation, filling, and completion can be found in the following functions in
(gets the required or allowed order price), and
(gets the required or allowed order size).
The order tracking logic can be found in the

The Perform Trade strategy includes logging operations for info, warnings, and errors. The info logs include information regarding transactions and is logged with severity info. The warning logs include information regarding warnings during a user's session, such as insufficient balance. Finally, the error logs include error information such as the markets being down or unable to connect to the markets and are stored with severity error.

The history command displays fulfilled orders, the balance snapshot, and performance analysis.
Most importantly for this strategy, the completed trades are shown by querying the database to see which transactions have occurred since the start of the session.
The logic for getting the history can be found in the balance_snapshot function, and trades list inside

If there is an order to place, check that the current timestamp is greater than the previous Order's timestamp plus delay time (e.g. current timestamp > previous Order's start timestamp +
If current time is valid time to place orders, call
NOTE : Can change delay interval by specifying
Cancel orders once their elapsed times go over a certain amount.
If there are active orders, check if order needs to be canceled (e.g. current_timestamp >= order's start timestamp +
If an order has to be canceled, call
NOTE : Can change cancel interval by specifying
When a specific event about the order is triggered, the event handler calls these logging methods to provide helpful information to the users.
sees that an order is filled.
sees that a buy order is completed.
sees that a sell order is completed.
These functions check to see if the order of interest is market or limit order and outputs appropriate text for each type.
